reviewText: In Rod's first concert dvd since 1998's "Storytellers", "It Had To Be You: The Great American Songbook" is a concert originally recorded in 2001 to promote his first "Great American Songbook" album, "It Had To Be You". Mixing several tracks from that album with the usual Stewart classics, it is not as great as the recent "One Night Only! Rod Stewart Live At The Royal Albert Hall", it is still an overall solid five star perfomance.The concert starts off with two energetic renditions of two of Rod the Mod's biggest hits, "Forever Young" and "Some Guys Have All The Luck", the latter tacking on "Every Breath You Take" at the end. Then comes 12 straight tracks from the "Great American Songbook" album. Now, I don't know why so many people dislike these songs, or at least Rod's versions. Stewart's raspy voice is perfect for these standards, just as Sinatra's and Crsoby's were on the original version. The live version breathes new life into these already great songs.After this half of the concert is over, Rod bounds back onstage to perform seven more Stewart classics. This is the only part of the show that is somewhat disappointing. While "Maggie May" and the rarely heard these days "Young Turks" are fine, the rest of the performances a re a mixed bag. "Rhythm Of My Heart" and "Downtwon Train" are never as good as the studio versions when performed live, as they lack the richness and excitement of the originals, and these workmanlike performances are no exception. And while "Hot Legs" is done really well here, the version on "One Night Only! Rod Stewart live At The Royal Albert Hall" blows this one out of the water. However, Rod rescues the concert from an average four star rating with pitch perfect renditions of "Havin' A Party", "I'll Be Seeing You" and "It Takes Two".Overall, again not as good as the Royal Albert Hall concert dvd, but definitely worth owning. It's not an overall excellent concert, but the majority of it is Rod at his best.
summary: Not As Good As "One Night Only" But  A Solid Show Overall

reviewText: Rod Stewart is truly a showman. His songs are delivered with enthusiasm and he makes all ot them great. He has been on the scene for many years and just seems to get better. This is one of his great DVD's. Highly recommended for Rod's fans.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have never been a Rod Steart fan... Until now... I caught the CD .. and the DVD was a must.  Rod takes the opportunity to "cross over" and bridge the gap of at least a couple of generations.  The shots of todays audience holding hands... cheek to cheek is back and warmer than ever.  He provides todays listeners with the common sense to listen to the lyrics and understand the meaning of them. One of the most noteable and less obvious is the lack of "brass and amplified percussion" in the band... mostly strings with a rythmn section highlighted by a single Trumpet or Sax solo to enhcnace the arrangement.The entire production is well executed and the background singers and set compliment the entire production. Rod has made the transition well and he will no doubt gather a whole new "army" of followers with this one.  Well done Rod... Congratulations.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a different Rod Stewart and I bought the dvd with some trepidation.  I am a big fan of Rod Stewart and also a big fan of the old standards.  I just wasn't sure these two worlds would mesh.  Not to fear.  Rod is no threat to Tony Bennett in this genre, but he does a great job on the excellent selection of old standards.  And as a bonus, you get some old Rod like Maggie May, Young Turks, Hot Legs and Downtown Train.  This is definitely a buy.
summary: A different kind of Rod and a good one at that.....

reviewText: If your a fan you must own Rod's FIRST EVER concert DVD !!!It is well put together, the picture quality is very good. The sound is perfect. The multiangle option is pretty cool and the extra stuff is nice too !!! And for this price, it's a steal. BUY IT TODAY, for yourself, a friend, and a family member !!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Some purists have given this performance and Rod's renditions of the old standards thumbs down.His unique style, the arrangements and the phrasing do these songs do them great justice and respect.He's as good as anyone at them.His voice is the perfect fit too.He invests just the right amount of feeling in each of them and performs with verve and humor.And in this DVD, a 50 year old man dancing among all the beautiful women (including musicians in red leather miniskirts).We got stuck to some extent for some decades in a Rock and Roll Dark Ages so more people are now receptive to songs that are more reflective and romantic.As a rocker he is accomplished; but when he sings songs of a more understated, more innocent and emotional and sentimental era he excels.Tony Bennett in his new incarnation and Harry Connick was perhaps the first to popularize them for new generations; and most recently McCartney, Elvis Costello, Madeleine Peyroux and so many others have been doing the old standards beautifully now and they are needed for the emotional balance we may have partially lost.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Watching this video is just having a ringside seat.  If you like the Frank Sinatra-like concertthen you will love this live concert on dvd.  The standard ballads sang here proves thatthese songs will never die.  Although Rod's voice does not compare with Sinatra, he has giventhese standard songs another extension of life.  Plus you get an additional bonus watching thereal Rod Stewart as a rock star do his real thing.
summary: just like having a ringside seat.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The rock hits on this DVD are not sung with the usual Rod gusto, instead he is still recovering from the throat surgery from a couple years previous. And the audience is a hand picked bunch of stiffs who add nothing. Rod sings the standards with respect but they don't sound much different from the CD. All in all, not a good performance, and definitely NOT like a real Rod concert. Skip this and go for the Storytellers AND the "Royal Albert Hall" DVDs--both are superior.
Title: N/A
